Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel combines possibly original travel footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1929) with descriptive intertitles, offering information and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler (ca. 1936). May also contain footage acquired by Miller from other soruces. Includes boats on a river, the "Wat Arun: The Porcelain Temple," the Wat Benchamabophit, statues of Buddha, a marketplace, many snakes, man fishing in a small boat, and close-up of license plate with title reading "A Siam auto license. Please read the numbers!!"
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 Siam "The Land of the White Elephant" Boat types on the River Mena, enroute to Bangkok. 00:01:46 Nearing the famous Wat Arun: the Porcelain Temple. 00:02:25 Wonderful workmanship! 00:02:32 The towers and images are built of bricks covered with plaster in which are encrusted thousands of bits of glazed tiles. 00:03:05 What we saw from one of the prangs or towers. 00:05:25 What one sees in the courtyard. 00:06:42 The Guards of the Gate; Wat Arun. 00:07:46 Our last view of the tallest prang, 235 feet high. 00:08:23 The King's guards and our guide at the Throne Hall. 00:09:20 We visit built of the choicest white marble from Carrara in Italy. A hand carved door. 00:09:47 Entrance to the Bot Wat Benchamabopitr. Notice wonderful workmanship. 00:12:22 Statues of Buddha in the gallery. 00:12:57 Wat Benchamabopitr seen from the outside. 00:13:14 A Siam auto license. Please read the numbers!! 00:13:28 What we saw on the streets of Bangkok. 00:19:27 End of recording.

Abstract#1: "Title from film container. Reel combines possibly original travel footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1929) with tinted footage (ca. 1936), possibly from another source. Added intertitles (ca. 1936) offer description and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler. Reel begins with decorative title reading ""Arriving at Java, the Gem of the Indian Ocean,"" and animated map of southeast Asia. Travel footage with decorative, identfying intertitles. Includes ""Weltevreden"" area street cars and canals, Bogor (""Buitenzorg"") Botanical Gardens, road to Bandung street scenes, rice fields, and markets, with people walking and working, washing things in the river, women carrying children, and a segment about traditional clothing.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 Arriving at Java "The Gem of the Indian Ocean". 00:00:09 An animation of a changing map to show geographic changes and where Java is. 00:00:39 Weltevreden boasts of a great street car and canal system. 00:02:04 We were here Thursday and Friday, but it seemed like Monday to us. 00:02:45 We visit the famed Botanical Gardens at Buitenzorg. 00:04:42 What we saw on the road to Bandeong. 00:11:54 A traffic officer in Bandeong. 00:12:12 Although Java is a crowded country-with 33,000,000 natives-the ruling Dutch colonials spread out their cities thus---. 00:12:40 We stroll down town---. 00:12:52 Markets are always fascinating places in the East---. 00:13:08 Women-the eternal shopper---. 00:13:25 Costumes curious in cut and color---. 00:13:42 We are in a chairless land of squatters---. 00:13:58 The Hokey-pokey man is also here---. 00:14:21 A long strip called a "Slendang" is used for carrying babies---. 00:14:46 A square of Batik makes the turban of the male---. 00:15:30 Turbanned princes never sally forth without a parasol of rank---. 00:15:43 Back again in Welevreden. Notice the many ways of transportation. 00:16:25 The sacred cannon. 00:16:56 A Javanese lady displaying her batik dress. 00:17:26 At the market in Batavia. 00:17:44 We sail from Java with a great desire to return. 00:17:51 End of recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel includes some original footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1929), original intertitles offering description and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler (ca. 1936). Additional footage and titles possibly acquired by Miller from another source, possibly Bray Studios. Titles may include derogatory or potentially offensive language, often toward local people. Opening sequence shows maps of the Philippines with description of hemp market and distribution of American goods. Sequence in Manila Bay - "unchanged since the day of Dewey's victory in 1898" - shows vinta and bangka boats, "Chinese junks" and American freight boats. Footage in Manila includes the "Constabulary Band;" street scenes with cars and "bullock" pulling carts with merchandise; people washing clothes and bathing in the Pasig River; and exterior images of a large hotel, the Army and Navy Club, and people marching in formation outside Bilibid Prison. Reel ends with shots of Filipino women posing in "native dress," men gathered outside a cock fighting ring, and a sunset.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 We arrive at MANILA at sunrise, the next morning. 00:00:25 Whenever the Philippines are discussed, some one invariable says, "They're more trouble than they're worth." Yet these 3000 islands produce everything from pepper to pearls and from tobacco to touring cars. 00:49 Animated map sequence showcasing where geographically the Philippines are. 00:01:04 Manila, the capital city, and the greatest hemp market in the world, is rapidly becoming the chief distributing center for all American goods consigned to the Far East. 00:01:24 Animated map picturing Manila. 00:01:32 Manila Bay, however, you will be pleased to find unchanged since the day of Dewey's victory in 1898. 00:02:08 Here are the same old "vintas" spreading their wings like giant birds of prey, sailing to and fro forever on their silent quests of fish. 00:02:43 And here, beyond the old Lighthouse you can still see Manila stretching out her arms to you, around the Bay. 00:03:14 Not until you have got inside the harbor, do you see how this fat old Spanish city has awakened from her sleep of centuries. 00:03:55 All along the brand-new wharves are vintas, bancas, Chinese junks, and American freighters,--eager messengers of commerce, waiting to be fed. 00:04:54 The wonderful Philippine Constabulary Band welcomes us. 00:05:42 The City also has undergone a transformation. Paved streets, trolley cars, motors, and electric lights, all testify to her vigorous awakening. And yet there still remains amid this clamor, the ambling bullock, that amiable beastie without which no Philippine family is complete. 00:07:56 The bullock is frequently the best looking member of thw household. Compare him, for instance, with the native woman of his class. 00:08:21 When you arrive at the Manila Hotel you find it a fit rival for the gigantic hostelries of the California coast. 00:08:47 The Army and Navy Club, to which you stroll for cafe noire, provides another glimpse of home. 00:09:11 A few minutes walk in any direction brings you to one of the many canals which suggest the city's name "The Venice of the Orient." 00:09:49 Through the heart of town runs the Pasig where all day long the native women bang the family laundry on great "washing stones." 00:10:18 And during all its winding length, the Pasig bathes the bullock and the boy impartially. 00:10:46 Bilibid Prison. Previous to American occupation it was full of pitiful wrecks of humanity who had been imprisoned without trial or hearing for many years. 00:11:05 Now it is one of the best in the world. 00:11:46 Two Filipino women wearing their native dress made from pina cloth or fiber of the pineapple leaf. 00:12:30 But among the Filipinos of the suburbs great cockingmains bear evidence of a vice which is still the curse of the whole race. 00:13:04 From this outward sign of an inward and innate barbarity, one turns gratefully again to the opal sea with its silent ships and softly lapping waters. 00:13:38 Great clouds drift on the Sky like phantom ships of long-dead Emperors: and from their sides, bursts of exotic color drop into the Garden of the Bay. 00:14:35 End of recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel combines possibly original travel footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1928) with tinted footage (ca. 1936), possibly from another source. Intertitles (ca. 1936) offer description and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler. Travel footage in Malaysia and Indonesida, indentified as "Penang, Prince of Wales Island" and "Sumatra." Includes footage of train ride through countryside; pagoda; local people going about their daily lives; policeman directing traffic; a circus traveling; local fashion such as batik pants; local architecture; and animals, including water buffalo and a monkey. Intertitles with descriptions and commentary describe people eating in a "native cafeteria." Includes footage of tourists gathering to board cruise ship, interacting with people playing music in costume or traditional dress.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 Our next port ~ Penang Prince of Wales Island. 00:00:08 The outstanding feature is the Hill Railway trip. 00:00:14 Footage of trains and the countryside. 00:01:56 We see our first Chinese pagoda. 00:02:22 Policemen directing traffic. 00:02:49 A native cafeteria. 00:03:08 There is much excitement on deck as we near the equator. We all look forward to the social call of King and Queen Neptune. 00:03:24 Footage of cruise ship life and the ocean. 00:04:20 Here they come! 00:05:18 After we had had the pleasure of meeting the King and Queen of the sea, this is what happened---. 00:08:38 The Royalty bids us good day after inviting us to visit their kingdom again. 00:08:48 We arrive at Sumatra. 00:08:54 Scenes taken from the train on our way to Padang. 00:10:12 This style should be popular with students batik pants. 00:10:35 The circus arrives at Padag. People watching the parade go by. 00:10:42 Bigger and better than Barnum & Baileys. Police had hard time keeping order. 00:12:19 A real enthusiast. 00:13:08 A native village in Sumatra. Notice design of home. 00:13:32 Noon time is resting time for these fellows. 00:14:10 What we saw going back to the "Resolute". 00:15:31 Mr. Monkey does his duty under protest! 00:16:42 End of recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel combines possibly original travel footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1929) with descriptive intertitles (ca. 1936), offering information and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler. May also contain footage acquired by Miller from other sources. Scenes include Mt. Lavinia, people in a group pounding nuts or grain, a boy playing with an animal - possibly a bear cub - and bathing elephants, sailboats, and people on beaches. Also includes footage of people on a cruise ship, playing shuffleboard, badminton, and other games, and three men posing for the camera.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 A series of shots showing people in a group pounding nuts or grain. 00:00:59 A shot of men circling a barrel pounding the perimeter. 00:01:11 A series of shots of boys playing with an animal, presumably a bear cub. 00:01:30 A series of shots of a boy bathing elephants. 00:02:33 Mt. Lavinia, one of the beauty spots of Ceylon 00:02:40 A series of shots of sailboats, people and kids playing on beaches, palm trees, trains, and presumably a resort. 00:05:19 Once again we are sailing eastward. Time never drags on shipboard. 00:05:27 Series of footage of people on a cruise ship, playing shuffleboard, badminton, and other games. 00:09:15 A series of shots of three men posing for the camera. 00:10:06 Footage of the ocean. 00:11:00 End of recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Producer unidentified. Film depicting a rubber "estate" in Selangor, Malaysia with title cards offering information and commentary from a Western perspective. Includes footage of local Tamil men and women working, supervised by British men. Includes sequences on tapping rubber trees, carrying buckets, straining and processing rubber in large vats, using machine rolls, hanging long strips of rubber to dry, and folding rubber sheets to pack and ship. Includes sequence on child workers folding rubber. Film ends with Tamil men and a child playing drums and dancing outdoors, some in body paint, while women and children watch nearby.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 The people of Selangor-one of the Federated Malay States-are of so languorous a nature that they let Tamil coolies do nearly all their rubbering---. 00:00:27 Vast and very profitable Rubber Estates have been developed by Indian labor backed by British enterprise---. 00:01:03 The rubber trees are tapped in the cool of the morning-very skillfully and carefully---. A white life-blood-the Rubber Latex-flows from each scientifically made wound---. 00:01:48 Delicate work-cutting just so much-Not more than an inch and a half a month---. 00:02:36 Two hours later the Latex is collected---. 00:03:01 Workers are paid according to the weight they bring----. 00:03:30 The creamy liquid rubber is strained into big jars---. 00:04:39 Acetic acid is added-and half an hour later the Latex is taken out in lumps---. 00:05:23 It is like handling half-head eels in chunks---. 00:06:04 Special machinery rolls it out in a long strips of rubber "crepe"---. 00:06:33 It takes a fortnight for this crepey drapery to dry---. 00:07:21 Then it is folded, packed and shipped---. 00:08:21 One baby worker is as pretty as a picture and bejeweled like a Hindu idol---. 00:09:17 All work and no play is not the rule---. 00:09:48 Every estate has its energetic orchestra---. 00:10:52 The men do all the dancing-The women merely "rubber"---. 00:11:17 Impish-irrepressible-and-dotty---. 00:11:56 So, when you buy a tire or an inner tube-think of these Tamil toilers who tap the rubber trees of far-away Selangor---. 00:12:23 End of recording

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel includes some original footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1929), original intertitles offering description and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler (ca. 1936). Additional footage and titles possibly acquired by Miller from another source. Titles may include derogatory or potentially offensive language, often toward local people. Reel begins with footage near Bangkok showing men riding elephants to pile and pull teak wood logs. Includes a crowded train ride through Borneo to the city of Tarakan, with footage of buildings, local people, and tourists in the streets. Extended sequence on Dayak people, referred to as "the Wild Men of Borneo," with images of men and boys in the city streets and close-ups on their haircuts and earrings. Intertitles describe the the practice of headhunting by Dayak men and claim that the men were ordered by the Dutch government to greet the cruise ship. Includes footage of a woman possibly shielding a child from being seen on camera. Groups of Dayak men board the "Resolute" cruise ship, with many sitting on the floor of the deck while men in traditional dress dance and play instruments. Reel ends with footage in Zamboanga, Philippines, with footage of outrigger boats shots from the deck of the cruise ship. Includes images of a coconut grove, with tourists posing in a pile of coconuts, and a "Moro village," with buildings, boats, local people in the streets, and a police officer.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 A short distance from Bangkok we watch----. 00:00:07 "Elephants a pilin' Teak"-we find them beginning their day's work---. 00:00:28 Intelligent team work---. 00:00:48 Pachydermic push!---. 00:01:26 Now! All together!!---. 00:01:50 "In the sludgy squdgy creek"-they are equally efficient---. 00:02:40 Tractors extraordinary!---. 00:03:29 ---with a pull as powerful as their push---. 00:14:13 We all agree that Bangkok is one of the highlights of a World Cruise. 00:04:23 We arrive at Borneo-"The Land of Wild Men". 00:04:32 We catch the 20th Century Limited for Tarakan. 00:04:38 The train was so FAST that I was able to get off, walk ahead two blocks, take this picture, and then walk back and get on the observation car!! The main street of TARAKAN, Borneo. 00:06:58 Homes occupied by white people. 00:07:24 Our first glimpse of the Dyaks, the Wild Men of Borneo. 00:08:15 We were the first group of white people to see these strange people. 00:08:26 By order of the Dutch Government these men were ordered to walk and cut their way through jungles to be at Tarakan at our arrival. 00:08:44 Here they are. Notice ear rings and the results: Before they can marry they must behead someone and present---. 00:09:00 the head to their sweethearts. The Dutch Government forbids this, but nevertheless it is done to this day. 00:10:45 The Wild Men march to the "Resolute" to give us their dance. 00:10:55 They had never seen a steamship before, and they were afraid to come on board. The way they looked on the ship: Musicians and the dance. 00:14:26 A new type of bob! 00:14:42 As we sailed away from Borneo we felt sorry for those who had to live there. 00:14:54 The next morning we let out a shout of joy at the sight of "Old Glory" once again!! 00:15:08 Outriggers come out to great us at Zamboanga, P.I. 00:15:55 We visit one of the largest cocoanut groves in the world. 00:16:29 A Moro village. 00:17:38 A Filipino home in a beautiful setting. 00:17:55 We see many magnificent sights. 00:18:41 We didn't blame the policeman for standing under an umbrella! 00:19:01 A gorgeous view of our "home". 00:19:19 End of recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel combines possibly original travel footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1928) with tinted footage (ca. 1936), possibly from another source. Added intertitles (ca. 1936) offer information and commentary from the perspective of a Western traveler, sometimes with derogatory or potentially offensive language. Intertitles describe Singapore as a “a British city on a Malay island,” with “a quarter million Chinese business men, Tamil toilers, and reposeful native sons, policed by Indian Sikhs and ruled justly by British gentlemen.” Images include street scenes with cars, carts, and trolleys; many types of boats on water, including “sampan” shelter boats; exterior images of mosques and temples, with close-ups on statues and architectural detail; a “Chinese funeral” procession, with people and cars carrying flowers and signs; an ox cart pulling an advertisement for Triangle Keystone films; and a policeman directing traffic with a large board. Includes shots of sap harvested from rubber trees and extended sequence on tapioca plantation, including man pulling roots of tapioca plants, wagons of roots pulled by ox, men and women sorting roots and carrying baskets, tapioca processed in vats and dried on large trays, and close-ups of Tamil women working. Also includes close-up portraits of “priests,” “Parsees,” and children, with commentary on their hair and clothing.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 Our next Port, Singapore "The Crossroads of the World". 00:00:09 We are taken first to Johore to see the mosque, and then to the large rubber plantations. 00:00:50 Catching the sap. Doesn't look as if this would make a good tire, does it? 00:01:19 In Singapore we see many travelers palms. They are pictures of beauty. 00:02:38 Singapore is one of Britain's brightest places in the sun---. 00:02:51 Here England sits-with cool, calm equanimity-almost astride the sizzling Equatorial Circle---. 00:03:05 Behold a British city on a Malay island with its quarter million Chinese business men, Tamil toilers and reposeful native songs-policed by Indian Sikhs and ruled justly by British gentlemen---. 00:03:33 ---and enriched by the commerce of the seven seas---. 00:03:42 Crowded neighboring China sends her sons to wax rich in the shops and offices of Singapore---. Crowded India sends her sweating coolies to bear the black man's burden-and to worship her gods in Hindu Temples---. 00:04:28 Priests of a cult older than that of Buddha---. 00:04:42 Hair longer than that of the idols of the musical world---. 00:04:53 On breast and brow the mark of Hindu caste---. 00:05:10 Plutocratic Parsees from Bombay rear picturesque progeny---to inherit their treasure---. 00:05:26 Every street is a living moving picture-but the cosmopolitan crowds spend their money at the movies just as we do---. 00:05:52 Every shop is rich in color-especially the Chinese tailor shops---. 00:06:23 A half billion dollars worth of merchandise is moved every season by the "Mosquito Fleet" of junks and lighters---. 00:06:52 Among the important articles of export is the Tapioca from large plantations in the Malay States---. 00:07:19 Tapioca bushes flourish in friendly rivalry with Rubber and Betel on the same plantation---. 00:07:35 The root furnishes the Tapioca---. 00:07:58 Load after load comes to the "Center"---. 00:08:31 Tamil men and women, calmly active, feed the crusher---. 00:09:13 All have Tapioca on the brain---. 00:09:21 Crushed, pulverized and washed, the Tapioca pours into rats---. 00:09:35 Solidifying, it is removed in masses---. 00:09:51 Dried, it separates into millions of pure and perfect spheres---. 00:10:18 Behold the Tamil maiden!-She toils and toils and is arrayed like Solomon in all his glory-with diamonds in her nose and solid silver around her bare black ankles---. 00:11:00 She earns just fifteen cents a day-and saves sixteen of it---. 00:11:19 Back to Singapore the Capital of the Straits Settlements- which include Penang, the Dindings and Malacca---. 00:11:43 We also see our first trackless street car. 00:12:03 A Chinese funeral. 00:12:32 At a Chinese temple guarded by two Dog Fos. 00:13:30 Another Chinese funeral. 00:13:53 A fishing village on the outskirts of the city. 00:14:33 Policemen of Singapore are clever. 00:15:31 Our first view of Sampans and boat life. 00:17:22 A Fuller Brush man? 00:17:42 End of recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel combines possibly original travel footage by Leroy H. Miller (ca. 1929) with descriptive intertitles, offering information and commentary from the perspective of an American traveler (ca. 1936). May also include footage acquired by Miller from other sources. Title on screen reads "Statue of Buddha Wat Po." Footage inside and outside Wat Pho Buddhist temple and Grand Palace in Bangkok Thailand, including footage of gold and wooden statues and close-ups on architectural details. Adults and children walk visit the buildings, and some people dance inside the temple, with close-up images of their clothing and headwear.
Note#2: As original, historical material, some of the language used and opinions shared in these films - especially regarding topics of race, gender, class religion, and ability - do not reflect the current preferred terminology of individuals of marginalized identities, or the values and norms of the CU Boulder Archives.
Note#3: 00:00:00 Statues of Buddha, Wat Po. 00:00:24 We are thrilled again with many beautiful and strange sights. 00:00:53 Stone giants guard this entrance. 00:01:07 A bashful family and more views of the most extensive temple in Bangkok. 00:02:40 The entrance to the Grand Palace and general view. 00:03:24 We see strange roofs that are gorgeous in color and design. 00:04:21 Teasing the cat. 00:04:41 What one sees in the temple area. 00:10:12 We leave the Palace Grounds with regret. It is wonderful! 00:11:04 End of recording.
